title: 112_hr2139
content: The "Lions Clubs International Century of Service Commemorative Coin Act" recognizes Lions Clubs International as the world's largest service club organization, founded in 1917 by Melvin Jones. With over 1.35 million members in 45,000 clubs globally, Lions Clubs International promotes humanitarian efforts, peace, and international understanding. In 1945, the organization was one of the first NGOs to assist in drafting the United Nations Charter. In 1968, Lions Clubs International Foundation was established to assist with global humanitarian projects, awarding over $700 million for various areas of service. In 1990, the foundation launched the SightFirst program to prevent blindness and improve eye care, raising over $415 million. Lions Clubs International will celebrate 100 years of community service in 2017. The Lions Clubs International Foundation has provided 100 years of community service to those in need worldwide. The Secretary of the Treasury will mint $1 silver coins in commemoration of the centennial, with specific specifications. The coins will be legal tender and considered numismatic items. The design of the coins will meet certain requirements. The coins minted under this Act will symbolize the centennial of Lions Clubs International, with specific inscriptions and designs. The design will be chosen by the Secretary in consultation with relevant committees and reviewed by the Citizens Coinage Advisory Committee. The coins will be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities. The coins minted under this Act will be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities at a designated Mint facility. The Secretary may only issue these coins during the calendar year starting on January 1, 2017. The sale price of the coins will include the face value, a surcharge, and the cost of designing and issuing the coins. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted. Prepaid orders for coins minted under this Act will be accepted by the Secretary before issuance, with sale prices at a reasonable discount. All sales of coins will include a $10 surcharge per coin, with surcharges promptly paid to Lions Clubs International Foundation for programs benefiting the blind, visually impaired, disabled, youth, and disaster-affected individuals. The Lions Clubs International Foundation will be audited for funds received under this Act. No surcharge can be included for issuing coins if it exceeds the annual limit. The Secretary will ensure that minting coins under this Act will not result in financial issues. SEC. 9. BUDGET COMPLIANCE. The budgetary effects of this Act will be determined by reference to the latest statement for compliance with the Statutory Pay-As-You-Go Act of 2010. The Chairman of the Committee on the Budget of the House of Representatives must submit a statement before the vote on passage.
